review: First, let me preface this by saying that I'm a huge android and google fan. I use almost all of their services and have owned google tvs (sucked), multiple tablets and at least 5 android flagship phones (currently the note 3).That being said.. this device is a solution to a problem that does not exist.First, it needs an intermediary wireless network to ride on and communicate with your phone/tablet. This means it's completely worthless for travel unless you bring your own wireless AP, as you'll never get the proper speeds (and likely ports opened) to work in a hotel anywhere.Second, if this is really just intended for home use, there's a myriad of devices that all do what it promises to do, way better. Most modern TVs, rokus, game systems or even blu-ray players have at least the same functionality, if not more. You're limited to about 6 pre-determined apps, like NetFlix, Pandora, Hulu, Youtube, etc. My TV does all of those already, plus it has Plex, HBO Go, etc. If it had screen sharing and let me broadcast anything, then it would be worth somethingThird, it DOES have wifi-direct! but that's only for initial configuration, what a waste.Finally, here was my ideal scenario in which it would fail: On travel for work, have some downtime at my hotel, don't want to watch their TV. Plug this into the HDMI port, connect to my phone which has unlimited LTE data and stream my media from home (plex), HBO Go, Netflix or whatever, without relying on the hotel's wifi. Nope, that's not going to happen with this device.

review: For college students with WiFi, this is a great way to "get cable" without having to have a smart TV or a cable subscription. With Hulu, Netflix, and Pandora, this is a quick and easy way to get big-screen entertainment on a budget. I look forward to more capabilities, and the ease of sending items from your smartphone to the device is brilliant.
